page.title: 02Landscape of South Benfleet.
page.content: Sth Benfleet developed around the creek on rising ground above the marshes which are now drained and used as playing fields.Modern houses cover much of the surrounding hills,whose steep wooden slopes cut it off from the uplands of Thundersley and Hadleigh and made it dependent on river transport.The first settlers arrived by boat; the Saxon name Beomflet means a wooded waterway. Vikings anchored their ships in the Creek before King Alfred's troops ousted them in 896 AD.A thriving port was maintained in the Middle Ages and now the Yacht Club continues the river connection.The railway line,too,runs along the Creek and salt air greets passengers alighting at the station. Hadleigh Country Park stretches across Benfleet Downs and 3 working farms add to the semi_rural aspect.
